text: Europe agrees to offer a second large

reporting for business day live first
here's a look at headlines investors are

it would be the highest point the Dow
has reached since the financial crisis
in 2008 Walmart's profit fell short of
analysts expectations still this was the
second consecutive quarter the company
turned a profit after more than two
years of declines the retail giant was
helped by holiday sales and Home Depot
said that warm weather and an improving
job market helped bolster its sales was
increased by five point seven percent
for the year European leaders agreed to

terms of the deal austerity for Athens
and a loss for bondholders joining me
now from Paris to discuss the deal is

so first things first you know what's
kind of the big picture here what does

euro zone for the future of Greece well
as you mentioned this is the second
bailout that Greece has had to get
within the space of two years and there
was a lot of strum and Drang surrounding
the final negotiations here they now
basically are on their way to getting
172 a billion dollars worth of aid which
is expected to carry them toward the

means is that Greece theoretically is

but the picture gets murky when you look

government still has to pass laws that

that they have agreed to and what what
what kind of austerity measures are we
talk
about here the government is going to be
doing everything from reducing salaries
further in the private sector lowering
the minimum wage sharply cutting defense
spending and it's also going to have to
try to make good on pledges that it is

more taxes in order to fill this gaping

know we've heard about Greece having to

what's the likelihood that this new
batch will actually materialize I mean
that's the you know billion dollar

especially has doubted Greece's ability
to do this because they have certainly

this we also saw a lot of opposition

while the politicians are pledging that

you know there's there's likely to be
some pain on Greece's and what does all

bondholders the banks that hold Greek
bonds have agreed to take a very large

percent on the bonds that they held that
should you know be a one-time deal that
being said there could be a number of
bondholders who decide at the end of the

the agreement which would create new
trouble because it would mean that
Greece would go ahead and try to
unilaterally impose losses on hedge
funds and others who wouldn't have
signed on to the agreement which would
effectively constitute sort of a
controlled default so that's something
that markets are going to be watching
out for very closely in the coming days
there's also a lot of concern about
financial contagion in all of this I
mean there has been for now several
years what does this deal do with regard
to up to a firewall and you know how
would that work to protect basically the

well the one thing that is different
this time around
is that politicians in Europe seemed to
have succeeded in calming the fever that
had gripped financial markets really for
the last almost 2 years on this issue
previously the concern was that if
something happened to Greece that if we
sort of default for example that perhaps
other countries that were in trouble
such as Ireland or Portugal might follow

people are convinced that Greece is
basically sort of a standalone case so
the contagion effect is significantly
diminished and at the same time next

they set up that a huge bailout fund
that basically would act to protect
